definitions.sensetop: just for somethingjust to do something

examples.text: There is just one method that might work.
I decided to learn Japanese **just for fun**.
I waited an hour just to see you.
‘Can I help you?’ ‘No thanks, **I'm just looking**.’ *(= in a shop)*
It was just an ordinary day.
I **just want** to help.
I **just think** you should wait a bit.
We'll **just have to** hope for the best.
I'm **just saying** there are risks involved.
I'm just glad you're OK.
That's **just plain** stupid.
I **can't just** drop all my commitments.
This essay is **just not good enough**.
I didn't mean to upset you. **It's just that** I had to tell somebody.
This is not **just another** disaster movie—it's a masterpiece.
It has to be green—and **not just any** green, but a very precise shade of olive.
**Just because** you're older than me **doesn't mean** you know everything.
It **just kind of** happened.
If she doesn't like, that's **just too** bad.
I'm **just so** sick of this.
They just never give up.

definitions.sensetop: just over somethingjust under somethingjust after/before something just after/before…just prior to somethingjust short of something

examples.text: You've just missed her.
They **just made it**, boarding the aircraft minutes before take-off.
I **only just** caught the train.
Inflation fell to just over 4 per cent.
The painting sold for just under £6 million.
I got here just after nine.
They must have got there just before I did.
He visited Guatemala just prior to his death.
They're now the largest party, through just short of an overall majority.

definitions.definition: used to say that you/somebody did something or something happened very recently
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)(especially North American English)North American EnglishNorth American EnglishBritish EnglishBritish EnglishNorth American English(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: I've just heard the news.
When you arrived, he had **only just** left.
She has just been telling us about her trip to Rome.
I just saw him a moment ago.
She was just here.
Just last week it was snowing and now it's 25 degrees.
I'm just finishing my book.
I was just beginning to enjoy myself when we had to leave.
I'm just off *(= I am leaving now)*.

definitions.sensetop: just like somebody/somethingjust what…just as…just on something

examples.text: This jacket is just my size.
With him, everything always has to be **just right**.
This gadget is **just the thing** for getting those nails out.
**Just my luck** *(= the sort of bad luck I usually have)*. My phone needs recharging.
You're **just in time**.
She looks just like her mother.
It's just what I wanted!
It's just as I thought.
It's just on six *(= exactly six o'clock)*.
The clock struck six just as I arrived.

definitions.sensetop: just as good, nice, easily, etc.

examples.text: She's just as smart as her sister.
You can get there just as cheaply by plane.

definitions.definition: going to do something only a few moments from now or then
definitions.sensetop: just about to do somethingjust going to do something

examples.text: The water's just about to boil.
I was just going to tell you when you interrupted.
The food was just wonderful!
The trip was just amazing!
Relax—you're doing **just fine**.
I can just imagine his reaction.

definitions.definition: used in orders to get somebody’s attention, give permission, etc.

examples.text: Just listen to what I'm saying, will you!
Just help yourselves.

definitions.definition: used to make a polite request, excuse, etc.

examples.text: Could you just help me with this box, please?
I've just got a few things to do first.

definitions.definition: used to show a slight possibility that something is true or will happen

examples.text: Try asking Mike—he might just know the answer.
‘He's very pompous.’ ‘Isn't he just?’

definitions.definition: used to say that you/somebody would have been in the same position if you had done something else, because you got little benefit or pleasure from what you did do

examples.text: The weather was so bad we might just as well have stayed at home.

definitions.definition: because of the possibility of something happening

examples.text: You'd better take the keys in case I'm out.
You probably won't need to call—but take my number, just in case.
In case *(= if it is true that)* you’re wondering why Jo’s here—let me explain…
It is just as well that we didn't leave any later or we'd have missed him.

definitions.definition: used to say that you would equally well like to do something as do something else that has been suggested

examples.text: I'd just as soon stay at home as go out tonight.
I've met just about everyone.
‘Did you reach your sales target?’ ‘Just about.’
She should be arriving just about now.

definitions.definition: used to ask somebody to wait for a short time

examples.text: ‘Is Mr Burns available?’ ‘Just a second, please—I'll check.’
Come and see me later—I'm busy just now.
Business is good just now.
I saw her just now.

definitions.definition: later; in a short period of time
done or arranged very accurately or carefully

examples.text: He liked polishing the furniture and making everything just so.
Just then, someone knocked at the front door.

definitions.definition: exactly what is needed in a particular situation

examples.text: That cup of tea was just the ticket.

definitions.definition: used when commenting on a situation to suggest that you could say something more or worse but prefer not to

examples.text: Let's just say he wasn't very happy about the decision *(= he was very unhappy or angry about it)*.

definitions.definition: not now but probably quite soon

examples.text: I can't give you the money just yet.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin justus, from jus ‘law, right’.
